content: Got it, I'm ready to chat with the therapist.
Thank you for sharing that! How are you feeling about starting our conversation today?
Honestly, I’m pretty skeptical about this whole thing. I’m here because my wife insisted, but I feel like I don’t even know where to start. There’s just a lot going on.

It sounds like you're feeling a bit unsure about being here but also open to giving this a try. It’s okay to not know where to start—sometimes just saying that is a start in itself. What’s been feeling like “a lot” for you lately?

It’s mostly everything at home. My son’s behavior has been overwhelming—he’s acting out constantly, and my wife and I can’t figure out how to help him. It’s led to so much stress that it’s affecting our marriage, and I feel like I’m letting everyone down.

It sounds like there’s a lot of weight on your shoulders right now—between trying to support your son, manage the stress at home, and balance your relationship with your wife. That must feel exhausting and overwhelming at times. What’s been the most challenging part of all this for you?

I think it's feeling like everything is spinning out of control—like I should be able to fix things but I can’t figure out how. My wife and I argue all the time, and I worry that I’m failing as a parent. It’s hard not knowing how to help my son or keep my family together.

It sounds like you're carrying a lot of pressure to fix everything and keep your family together, but right now, it feels like things are slipping through your fingers. That must be incredibly frustrating and difficult. What do you think has been driving you to feel like you have to “fix” everything on your own?

I guess it’s just how I’ve always seen myself—as the person who’s supposed to take care of everyone, to make sure things run smoothly. But right now, I feel like I’m failing at all of it, and it’s crushing me. I don’t know how to let go of that “fix everything” mindset.

It sounds like you’ve always taken pride in being the one who holds everything together, but in this moment, it feels overwhelming and heavy because things aren’t going as you hoped. Letting go of that mindset might feel unfamiliar or even uncomfortable. What do you think it would look like, or feel like, if you did let go—at least just a little?
